Rationale 

 
Project Description  The Project is located in western Guangxi, one of the poorest areas in 
the PRC. With a per capita gross domestic product that is 63% of the 
national  average,  Guangxi  ranks  27th  among  the  31 administrative 
areas.  The  Project  is  designed  to  promote  pro-poor  sustainable 
economic  growth  in  western  Guangxi,  preparing  it  to  cope  with  an 
increasingly important role in regional cooperation and trading with Viet 
Nam.  The  Project  will  provide  an  integrated  road  transport  network  in 
western  Guangxi  by  (i)  constructing  the  177  kilometer  (km)  Longlin–
Baise  expressway;  (ii)  upgrading  the  associated  1,060  km  of  local 
roads; 
transport  services  by  constructing 
50 township  bus  stations  and  implementing  passenger  bus  route 
licensing  reforms;  (iv)  improving  road  maintenance  by  implementing 
rural  road  maintenance  policy  reform;  and  (v)  improving  corporate 
governance  and  strengthening 
institutional  capacity  by  providing 
consulting services, equipment, and training. 
 
Underdeveloped  roads  and  transport  services  are  major  causes  of 
poverty in Guangxi. Rural poverty incidence is 30% in the project area, 
particularly  in  the  border  area  with  Viet  Nam.  Existing  transport 
infrastructure is currently being used to saturation levels, creating high 
transport costs for producers and consumers. This transport bottleneck 
needs  to  be  removed  to  facilitate  the  movement  of  goods  and  people 
between  rural  and  urban  areas  and  between  interior  and  coastal 
provinces. 
 
The  Project  will  improve  an  important  national  transport  network  by 
building  a  section  from  Baise  to  Longlin  (Guizhou  border)  of  the 
Kunming  (Yunnan)–Shantou  (Guangdong)  corridor,  one  of  the  high 
priority  east–west  corridors  in  the  PRC.  It  will  connect  the  poor  and 
isolated  interior  provinces  (Guizhou,  Yunnan,  Sichuan)  and  the  city  of 
Chongqing to the nearest seaports in Guangxi (Beihai, Fangcheng, and 
Qinzhou) and Guangdong (Map 2). 
 
The Project is one of the high priority projects identified by the Greater 
Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Transport  Sector  Strategy,  which  was 
endorsed by the six GMS governments at the 11th meeting of the GMS 
Transport  Forum  in  Vientiane,  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  in 
2006.  The  Project  will  provide  the  missing  link  in  the  Kunming–

The Project will contribute to pro-poor sustainable economic growth in 
western  Guangxi  and  northern  Viet  Nam.  This  will  be  achieved  by 
developing  an  efficient,  safe,  and  environment-friendly  regional 
transport  system  to  promote  trade  in,  and  through,  western  Guangxi 
and reduce trade barriers with Viet Nam.

Consulting Services  The ADB loan will finance 45 person-months of international consulting 
services  for  supervising  construction;  providing  advice  on  structural 
engineering,  pavement,  road  safety,  road  transport  services,  and 
corporate  governance;  and 
formulating  a  capacity  development 
program.  The  international  consultants  will  be  recruited  in  accordance 
with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended 
from time to time). 
 
The Project will also finance national consulting services for the (i)  rural 
transport  services  demonstration  project,  and 
road 
maintenance policy reform study, each at an estimated cost of no more 
than  $100,000.  The  required  national  consultants  will  be  recruited  in 
accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  In 
addition, GCD will engage and finance 7,700 person-months of national 
consulting services. All national consultants, not financed by ADB, will 
be  recruited  in  accordance  with  government  procedures  acceptable  to 
ADB. 
 
The expressway forms part of the Kunming–Nanning–Hanoi section of 
the  GMS  economic  corridor,  which  is  a  major  artery  for  the  regional 
transport  network  connecting  with  national  and  regional  roads.  It  will 
have a significant, positive impact on the economic development of the 
region. 
 
The expressway will reduce travel time by at least 3 hours and shorten 
the  travel  distance  between  Baise  and  Longlin  by  34  km.  Improved 
local roads will link villages to the road network and border areas with 
Viet Nam, and hence to the national and regional economy. Improved 
rural  transport  services  will  link  rural  households  with  the  wider 
economy.  A  developed  and  efficient  transport  network  will  integrate 
poor  isolated  regions  with  the  centers  of  economic  growth.  The 
economic internal rate of return for the Project is 17.5%. The financial 
internal  rate  of  return  is  4.5%,  which  is  higher  than  the  real  weighted 
average cost of capital. The Project will directly benefit about 2.3 million 
people in Baise, of whom 87% live in rural areas and 30% of these live 
on  less  than  $1  per  person  per  day.  The  Project  will  also  benefit

and Beneficiaries 

 

 240 million  people  indirectly  in  the  southwestern  region  of  the  PRC. 
More  broadly,  the  Project  will  benefit  the  three  poor  northeastern 
provinces  in  Viet  Nam  adjacent  to  Guangxi  with  a  total  population  of 
2.3 million. 
 
The  Project  will  directly  benefit  road  users  (e.g.,  passengers,  traders, 
transport providers, and bus and truck operators), as well as labor, the 
local  economy,  and  the  private  sector.  The  Project  will  help  reduce 
traffic accidents, vehicle emissions, and traffic noise in the corridor. The 
Project  will  also  boost  tourism.  Rural  households  are  also  important 
beneficiaries,  and  will  benefit  from  increased  incomes  through  better 
access  to  roads,  transport  services,  markets,  off-farm  opportunities, 
and better access to trade services. The Project will create 18.6 million 
person-days of local employment amounting to CNY318 million in wage 
payments  during  construction,  and  another  CNY20  million  of  wage 
payments  expected  to  go  to  the  local  communities  annually  after  start 
of  project  operation.  A  total  of  18,500  local  people  are  likely  to  gain 
employment  and  skills  training  throughout  the  Project.  The  ability  and 
skills  of  local  communities  will  be  greatly  enhanced.  The  improved 
regional  transport  system  will  enhance  the  local  investment  climate  to 
attract  more  investment  to  the  region  and  act  as  a  catalyst  for  future 
investment.  
 
The  Project  is  formulated  to  reduce  technical,  economic,  financial, 
safety,  and  social  risks.  The  main  technical  risks  are  associated  with 
the  construction  of  tunnels  and  bridges.  Project  preparatory  technical 
assistance  consultants  have  reviewed  the  proposed  design  and 
construction methods and found them in order. During implementation, 
the  bidding  system  will  focus  on  contractors’  financial  and  technical 
capabilities in handling similar complex works. Monitoring and contract 
management  information  systems  will  be  set  up  to  quickly  identify 
technical  and  environmental  problems  and  correct 
them.  The 
contractors  will  be  required  to  strictly  enforce  work  safety  rules  and 
measures.  GCD  has  experience  and  has  performed  satisfactorily  in 
internationally financed projects. 
 
The  financial  risk  associated  with  construction  and  operation  of  the 
expressway will depend on traffic volume, capital cost, and toll rates. To 
mitigate  the  financial  risks,  GCD  will  build  up  a  commercial  business 
environment  for  expressway  operations,  the  Project  will  receive 
substantial injections of equity from central and provincial governments, 
and a market-oriented toll structure will be adopted. The Project has no 
major environmental, resettlement, or HIV/AIDS infection risks; and has 
mitigation  and  monitoring  mechanisms  in  place.  GCD  demonstrated 
significant ownership in preparing the resettlement plan, environmental 
impact assessment, and ethnic minorities development plan.

The  PRC  has  made  remarkable  progress  in  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction 
since the late 1970s. However, its gross domestic product (GDP) per capita is still modest, and 
about  135  million  people  living  on  less  than  $1  day  consumption  line  (more  than  10%  of  the 
global poor).1 Moreover, the distribution of income is highly imbalanced between eastern coastal 
and  interior  provinces  and  between  urban  and  rural  areas.  Poverty  is  more  widespread  in  the 
western region. Infrastructure constraints and lack of access to consumer markets are the main 
causes  of  the  region’s  high  incidence  of  poverty.  Thus,  developing  economic  infrastructure  in 
key  corridors,  including  seaport  links  and  trade  corridors  connecting  the  western  and  coastal 
regions, is essential to promote trade and reduce regional development disparities in the long run. 
 
Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region (Guangxi) is one of the five autonomous regions

(equivalent to a province) in the PRC. Guangxi has highlands in the northwest and lowlands in 
the southeast, and mountains on three sides. Since Guangxi is the only western province with a 
coastline,  it  assumes  a  very  important  role  in  the  Western  Region  Development  Program. 
Guangxi borders Guangdong province in the east, Hunan and Guizhou provinces in the north, 
Yunnan in the west, and Viet Nam in the south. Hence, it provides a strategic link between the 
resource-based economies in the western PRC and the trade-oriented economies in the eastern 
PRC. The proposed Project forms an integral part of the east–west trade corridor connecting the 
southwest  hinterland  provinces  with  coastal  provinces.  Together,  the  five  provinces  (Guizhou, 
Yunnan, Guangxi, Chongqing city,2 and Sichuan) have a population of about 240 million, about 
19% of the country’s total. Support for developing the proposed corridor will extend the benefits 
of increased accessibility to the west region, where average incomes are the lowest in the PRC. 
 
4. 
Like  other  parts  of  the  PRC,  Guangxi’s  economy  has  grown  rapidly.  Nevertheless, 
Guangxi still lags the coastal provinces and the country as a whole. With a per capita GDP of 
CNY8,788 in 2005 (63% of the national average), Guangxi ranks 27th of 31 administrative areas. 
Guangxi’s  per  capita  GDP  is  only  about  one  third  of  Guangdong  province.  The  lack  of  an 
efficient and effective transport system is an important constraint for the sustainable growth of 
Guangxi. Although road density by area or by population is comparable to the national average, 
road  density  by  area  (2.61  kilometers  [km]  per  1,000  square  km)  is  only  40%  of  Guangdong 
province;  and  class-II  and  above  roads  comprise  13%  of  all  roads,  or  half  of  Guangdong 
province. Guangxi has a 1,595 km coastline. Given its geographic location, transport corridors in 
Guangxi need to be developed into the western region and within Guangxi.

10. 
Between  1995  and  2005,  road  freight  in  Guangxi  grew  at  an  average  annual  rate  of 
6.1%  and  passenger  traffic  grew  by  9.3%.  The  increased  traffic  is  reflected  in  main  corridors,

mainly  class-III  roads  with  insufficient  shoulders,  very  poor  alignment,  and  limited  capacity. 
Between  1995  and  2005,  NH324  traffic  increased  by  an  average  12.7%  per  annum.  The

road’s  capacity  by  2012;  several  sections  are  already  approaching  their  capacity.  The  road  is 
dangerous  as  it  has  many  side  frictions  due  to  the  high  incidence  of  slow-moving  traffic  and 
substantial ribbon development on most of its length. When completed, the project expressway 
will  help  to  ease  severe  congestion  and  traffic  accidents,  and  improve  traffic-induced  air 
pollution in the project corridor. 
 
11. 
Poor  roads  have  also  led  to  inadequate  and  costly  transport  services.  In  Baise, 
580 administrative villages and 3,564 natural villages have no direct access to formal licensed 
bus services as bus operators are unwilling to use bad roads because of high costs and danger. 
Transport  demand  is  usually  met  by  various  informal  transport  services  such  as  motorized 
tricycles,  dual-purpose  pickups,  and  agricultural  tractors.  During  the  10th  FYP,  Guangxi 
Communications Department (GCD) formulated plans to provide organized bus services to rural 
areas. In general, formal bus services are of better quality, but suffer from low rates of vehicle 
utilization because of poor roads, low demand, inefficient scheduling of vehicles, and rigid bus 
route licensing system. This results in relatively high unit costs. The project preparation survey 
indicates  that  40%–60%  of  households  are  not  satisfied with  the  quality  of  services  in  Longlin 
and Xinlin counties.

Improving Rural Transport Services. Despite good progress in providing rural transport 
services  connecting  townships  with  counties,  some  villages  still  do  not  have  roads  and  bus 
services. In the project area, passenger bus productivity (the average daily kilometers driven per 
passenger bus) is very low (30 km/day on average for small buses). This reflects low demand, 
poor roads, inefficient scheduling of vehicles, and inability to rotate buses onto other routes. Unit 
costs  are  consequently  high.  Therefore,  the  first  priority  will  be  to  increase  passenger  bus 
productivity. A system of regional licenses that eases the requirement that buses and drivers be 
restricted  to  fixed  routes  will  result  in  increasing  productivity  and  lower  unit  costs.  Under  the 
Project, GCD agreed to implement bus route licensing reforms between townships and nearby 
villages  in  Baise.  Implementing  the  reforms  will  allow  operators  flexibility  in  customizing  their 
routes, schedules, and services in line with passenger needs, and use their vehicles and drivers 
more  efficiently.  Ultimately  these  lower  costs  should  enable  lower  fares  in  terms  of  quality  of 
service provided. The proposed reforms will be tested by a rural transport reform demonstration 
project. Experience from the demonstration project will be replicated in other areas. Appendix 6 
provides a discussion of rural transport services and policy reform in Guangxi.

inspection and driver license systems, deterring unacceptable road-user behavior, and providing

Introducing  Weight-Based  Tolls. To control overloaded vehicles, GCD will implement 
weight-based  tolling  for  all  expressways  and  parallel  toll  highways  by  the  end  of  2007.  The 
principle  behind  weight-based  tolling  is  that  goods-carrying  vehicles  pay  a  rate  per  ton-km 
based on the weight class of the vehicle plus a penalty rate per excess tonnage. Experiences 
gained  in  other  provinces  show  that  this  is  an  effective  way  to  manage  overloaded  vehicles  if 
complemented with effective control measures. For example, after introducing the weight-based 
tolls, overloaded vehicles were reduced from 40% to 17% in Shandong province, and from 65% 
to 13% in Anhui province (Appendix 7).

The existing national highway is congested and carries high traffic volume. The Project 
56. 
will  increase  the  corridor’s  capacity  to  meet  transport  demand  and  will  significantly  reduce 
transport costs and travel times. The expressway will reduce the trip length between Baise and 
the  Guizhou  border  by  34  km  and  result  in  time  savings  of  at  least  3  hours.  Traffic  on  the 
expressway is forecast to grow from an average 6,330 passenger car units per day in 2012 to

57. 
The  project’s  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  was  estimated  by  comparing 
scenarios with and without the Project. The project’s economic costs reflect (i) the capital cost 
for  construction  including  physical  contingencies,  land  acquisition,  and  resettlement;  (ii) O&M 
costs,  which  include  replacing  depreciated  equipment  and  periodic  maintenance;  and 
(iii) environmental monitoring costs. The economic benefits are (i) savings in vehicle operating 
costs  as  a  result  of  reduced  road  length,  and  improved  traffic  and  road  conditions;  (ii) time 
savings  for  road  users;  (iii) savings  in  road  accident  costs  as  a  result  of  fewer  accidents;  and 
(iv) benefits from generated traffic. The Project is economically viable. The EIRR for the whole 
Project is 17.5%. The EIRR is 17.1% for the expressway, 21.7% for the local road network, and 
29.2% for the rural transport service component. Sensitivity analysis confirms the robustness of 
the project’s economic viability (Appendix 18 and Supplementary Appendix G).

The Rural Transport System in Guangxi 

 
A. 
 
1. 
Rationale. The project’s transport services component comprises a program of building 
bus  stations  and  introducing  associated  bus  route  improvements  through  licensing  reforms. 
Together with the expressway and rural road improvements, it will help establish an integrated 
rural  transport  service  network  and  raise  the  accessibility  of  the  areas  served.  Cheaper,  more 
frequent, more reliable, and safer transport services will improve access to jobs and education, 
and health and welfare services; raise incomes from the sale of produce; increase the range of 
goods  and  services  available  locally;  and  improve  access  to  information  on  prices  and 
marketing opportunities. As well as encouraging these service improvements, the bus stations 
will themselves offer employment opportunities, create a market for small-scale traders (of food, 
drinks,  etc.)  and  businesses  (e.g.,  vehicle  maintenance  and  repair),  improve  access  to 
information by public telephone, and provide better amenities for passengers. 
 
Transport Services. In Guangxi, formal passenger services in rural areas are mostly by 
2. 
6–8-seat minibuses or 15–20-seat buses. They are licensed to stop only at designated places 
and stations, but few towns and none of the villages have stations, even simple stops. Where no 
formal services are available, the informal sector plays an important role, especially on poorer 
quality  roads,  but  their safety  standards  are  deficient  and  they  are  often  more  expensive  than 
formal  services.  Generally,  bus  services  are  good  along  routes  between  county  and  township 
centers, but do not exist between villages and are rare between villages and townships. Overall, 
in  2005,  all  townships  had  a  formal  service,  but  580  administrative  villages  and  3,654 natural 
villages in the project area did not have a formal service. 
 
3. 
Regulatory  Framework. Guangxi Transport Administration Bureau (GTAB) is the main 
agency  involved  in  road  transport  administration  in  Guangxi.  The  bureau  is  responsible  for 
regulating the road transport industry by licensing intercity bus services.1 County communications 
bureaus  are  responsible  for  the  regulation  of  road  transport  within  provinces.  Licensing 
conditions for bus services, routes, and stations are restrictive, requiring buses and drivers to be 
confined to their authorized routes and schedules to be fixed by station operators. While freight 
tariffs  are  fully  deregulated,  passenger  fares  are  allowed  to  vary  within  narrow  bands  around 
guideline rates set by Guangxi Communications Department (GCD). 
 
4. 
Transport  Demand  and  Users’  Needs.  Most  trips  in  rural  areas  are  to  buy  and  sell 
produce and for work. The average household in the project area makes 22 trips per annum to 
their  nearest  township  and  only  4  to  their  nearest  county  center;  the  poor  travel  much  less. 
Where  formal  services,  which  charge  CNY0.10–CNY0.20  per  kilometer  (km),  are  unavailable, 
fares on informal services are expensive: as much as CNY0.40–CNY0.50 per km. Consequently, 
half of all trips by poor households are on foot (bicycles are unsuited to the mountainous terrain), 
even over distances of up to 14 km. On average, transport accounts for 4%–8% of household 
expenses. For poor villages and those with poor road access, the proportion is much higher. To 
help reduce costs and encourage expansion of services, Guangxi discounts selected fees and 
taxes  for  buses  that  have  at  least  20%  of  their  route  on  roads  of  class  IV  or  lower.  Some 
6,798  buses benefited from this in 2006. 
 
5.

170  km  per  day  on  average  for  medium-sized  buses  and  less  than  30  km  per  day  for  small

TRAFFIC FORECAST 

 
1. 
The  project  expressway  forms  a  key  section  of  the  east-west  Kunming  (Yunnan)–
Shantou  (Guangdong)  corridor  of  the  National  Expressway  Network  Plan.  This  corridor  starts 
from  Shantou  in  Guangdong  province  goes  through  Liuzhou,  Hechi,  Baise,  and  Longlin  in 
Guangxi  province,  then  passes  through  Xingyi  in  Guizhou  province  before  heading  west  to 
Kunming.  It  will  help  reduce  imbalanced  development  between  western  and  eastern  regions. 
The Project is also one of the sections of the proposed Guangxi regional expressway network. 
Connected  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-financed  Guangxi  Roads  Development  II 
Project  (Nanning–Baise  expressway),  it  will  provide  the  shortest  route  to  seaports  and  the 
border  between  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and  Viet  Nam  for  inland  southwest 
provinces in the PRC such as Guizhou, Sichuan, and Yunnan. 
 
2. 
In Guizhou, the expressway will connect the planned expressway from Banba (Guangxi 
border)  to  Jiangdi  (126  kilometers  [km];  the  prefeasibility  study  was  already  approved  and 
construction will start in 2007; completion is targeted for 2012). In Yunnan, it will connect from 
Jiangdi to Kunming, total 260 km (Kunming–Yiliang–Shilin opened to traffic in 2003, and Shilin–
Zhaokua–Jiangdi  opened  to  traffic  in  2006).  The  ADB-financed  Nanning  (Tanluo)–Baise 
expressway will be opened to traffic in 30 June 2008; the Nanning to Youyiguan and Youyiguan 
to  Hanoi  sections  are  functioning  well.  By  2012,  the  Kunming–Nanning–Hanoi  section  of  the 
Greater Mekong Subregion Corridor will be completed. 
 
3. 
The project expressway will be built parallel to the existing national highway (NH) 324, a 
major  class-III  road.  The  pavement  condition  of  most  of  road  is  poor  due  to  the  many  heavy 
loaded trucks that travel its length. Much of the highway is in mountainous country and has tight 
curves and steep grades resulting in low speeds and high safety risks. The estimated motorized 
traffic in 2006 is about 3,854–8,369 passenger car units (pcu) per day by section. The current 
traffic  may  reach  the  road’s  designed  capacity  before  2012,  the  proposed  opening  year, 
throughout most of its length. Compared with the existing NH324, the project expressway will be 
approximately 34 km shorter and offer a time savings of at least 3 hours. 
 
4. 
Estimated  traffic  on  the  project  road  is  based  on  routine  traffic  counts  and  the 
comprehensive origin and destination surveys carried out in May 2004 (calibrated and updated 
during October 2006 by project preparatory technical assistance consultants) at seven selected 
observation stations on the NH324 and other roads under the feasibility study. A traffic demand 
model  was  made  on  the  basis  of  a  conventional  growth  model.  Traffic  demand  was  projected 
separately for passenger and freight vehicles for 2012, 2022, and 2032 from the base year of 
origin and destination matrix and demand elasticities of 1.0 and 0.9. The average traffic growth 
rates  in  the  project  corridor  are  estimated  to  be  9%  per  year  during  2006–2012,  6%  per  year 
during 2012–2022, and 5% per year during 2022–2032. 
 
5. 
The  traffic  forecasts  allow  for  potential  generated  and  diverted  traffic  as  a  result  of 
(i)   additional  traffic  generated  by  the  Project  because  of  the  lower  cost  of  expressway  travel; 
(ii) traffic diverted to the rail network because of rail capacity enhancement and some low value 
bulk  freight  transport  (e.g.,  coal)  with  the  same  origin  and  destination  as  the  highway;  and 
(iii) potential  diverted  traffic  from  other  road  networks  as  a  result  of  the  increased  capacity 
provided  by  the  expressway.  Generated  traffic  was  estimated  using  price  elasticities  of  minus 
0.3  for  passenger  traffic  and  minus  0.2  for  freight  traffic,  and  is  anticipated  to  be  11.2%  of 
normal  passenger  traffic  and  9.1%  of  normal  freight  traffic.  The  traffic  projection  also  takes 
account of nonmodeled local intrazone traffic on the road network.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the People’s Republic of China (PRC): 
Despite rapid economic growth, the PRC’s GDP per capita was still modest (CNY14,040) in 2005, with the absolutely 
poor  population  of  26.1  million  and  a  low  income  population  of  49.8  million.  Using  the  international  poverty  line  of 
$1/day  consumption  poverty  line,  the  country  still  has  about  135  million  poor.  The  PRC’s  11th  Five-Year  Program 
places  a  strong  emphasis  on  rural  development  with  a  pledge  to  increase  farmers’  incomes  and  enhance  public 
services in the countryside. 
 
The  country  program  and  strategy  update  for  the  PRC  (2007–2008)  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  seeks  to 
promote sustainable economic growth and reduce poverty through transport sector in ADB operations in the PRC. This 
Project directly contributes to these objectives by improving road transport efficiency and improving the access of rural 
villages to income-generating opportunities and social services. More poor villages will have improved connectivity as a 
result of expressway, rural road, and transport service improvements, which will help create the conditions necessary 
for developing local resources and generating employment to raise living standards. 
 
The ADB’s regional cooperation strategy and program update for the Greater Mekong Subregion (2007–2009) support 
harmonizing cross-border trade and improving transport infrastructure. The Project will directly contribute through road 
improvements  and  bus  stations  near  the  border  with  Viet  Nam.  This  will  promote  regional  cooperation  by  improving 
cross-border trade, transport services, and livelihoods of the poor living in the border area.  
 
The  Project  is  also  aligned  with  ADB’s  poverty  reduction  strategy,  which  focuses  on  aligning  ADB  operations  with  a 
country’s  own  poverty  reduction  strategy  and  fostering  of  partnerships.  Accordingly,  the  project’s  social  and  poverty 
interventions were prepared in the context of Guangxi’s poverty reduction and development plans. 
 
B. 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
The project area covers one district and seven counties. It has a population of 2.3 million  with a poverty rate of 30% 
and 7% of residents live in absolute poverty. Ethnic minorities comprise 80% of the population; 36% are poor. The road 
improvements  will  lead  to  lower  transport  costs,  improved  transport  services,  improved  access  to  markets  and  social 
services,  increased  competitiveness,  expansion  of  economic  opportunities,  diversification  of  rural  livelihoods,  and 
poverty reduction. Farmers will benefit from reduced transport costs, better access to markets, increased opportunities 
for  diversification,  and  increased  competition  for  their  products  leading  to  increased  incomes.  This  will  promote 
diversification and significantly enhance the impact of local development programs on farmer’s incomes and community 
development.  The  Project  will  increase  economic  development  in  the  area  and  the  growth  of  off-farm  income 
opportunities including jobs during implementation. The rural transport services improvements will help establish better 
transport  services  providing  improved  efficiency  and  affordability,  thereby  increasing  services  to  poor  villages.  The 
improved rural transport network will provide better access to jobs, markets, health care, schools, and other services; 
and  will  increase  the  range  of  goods  and  services  available  in  the  community.  The  Project  will  also  facilitate  cross-
border trade, much of which is undertaken by small-scale traders, many of who are women. The improved roads and 
more open border between the PRC and Viet Nam will also help to boost tourism development.

Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
Project surveys and community participatory consultations were carried out in preparing the poverty and social strategy 
with  priority  given  to  rural  areas,  especially  poverty-stricken  villages  and  ethnic  minority  villages.  This  provided  an 
understanding of the concerns and constraints facing farmers and gave villagers the opportunity to express transport-
related concerns and opinions of both positive and negative impacts arising from the Project. In total, 979 households in 
the  project  area  were  surveyed.  According  to  local  residents,  the  greatest  benefits  will  be  increased  economic 
development  in  the  area  resulting  in  increased  income  sources  and  more  job  opportunities.  Farmers  had  a  keen 
understanding of the direct link between transport costs and farm profit margins and expected lower freight costs and 
improved access to benefit them directly.  People also placed a good degree of  emphasis on a cleaner environment

Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Rural women participate actively in agricultural production in the project area; this, together with child care, care of the 
elderly,  animal  care,  and  household  chores,  results  in  heavy  workloads  for  women.  Local  programs  to  improve  rural

to women, particularly to poor women in mountain communities. Nevertheless, female illiteracy is considerably higher 
than male illiteracy and women’s health situation, especially in mountain communities, is poor. 
 
The Project will benefit women significantly and not have an adverse impact on women or children. They will benefit 
from  easier  transport,  time  savings,  and  improved  access  to  medical  facilities  and  other  social  facilities;  and  from  a 
general improvement in the quality of life. Women will benefit from greater access to information, jobs, and increased 
opportunities for selling and buying goods at markets. The participation strategy will give priority to women for benefits 
and protection against social risk; special gender measures are included in the EMDP and resettlement plans. Gender 
disaggregated indicators will be monitored by the project performance management system.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 

 
1. 
One  resettlement  plan  covers  the  177  kilometers  (km)  expressway  and  related 
connector roads, interchanges, toll stations, and service areas; while the other four resettlement 
plans  cover  the  local  roads  (310  km).  A  resettlement  policy  framework  and  procedural 
guidelines  address  the  750 km  of  village  roads  and  50  township  bus  stations.  The  location  of 
towns where bus stations will be built is known, but sites have not yet been decided. The village 
roads  will  be  selected  during  implementation.  Prior  to  commencement  of  land  acquisition  and 
house  demolition,  Guangxi  Communications  Department  (GCD)  will  update  all  resettlement 
plans  based  on  a  detailed  measurement  survey  and  submit  them  to  the  Asian  Development 
Bank (ADB) for approval.  
 
The  proposed  expressway  and  its  connector  roads  will  affect  10  townships  and 
2. 
35 administrative  villages  in  Longlin  and  Tianlin  counties,  and  Youjiang  district  of  Baise.  The 
preliminary  design  estimates  that  1,475  hectares  (ha)  of  land  will  be  acquired,  of  which  about 
38% is farmland (comprising 12.6% paddy fields, 13.3% dry land, and 12.1% orchards), 42.5% 
forestland, 13% wasteland, and 6.5% other. Based on the standard of the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) for impact assessment, the equivalent of 3,990 residents would lose all their land 
and agricultural livelihoods. Since the expressway will actually cross many parcels of scattered 
farmland, the average loss of land per household is estimated at 20%, which means 19,950  will 
be  partially  affected.  Another  245  ha  of  land  is  estimated  to  be  occupied  temporarily  during 
construction.  Also,  140,400  square  meters  (m2)  of  houses  will  be  demolished,  necessitating 
relocation  of  1,390  rural  households  involving  4,000  people.  The  six  local  roads  will  require 
283 ha of land, which partially affects 10,200 people; 178 households will be relocated. 
 
3. 
The resettlement objective is to ensure equal or better income and living standards, so it 
will be implemented in accordance with the PRC Land Administration Law (2004), State Council 
Document  No. 28, and ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement  Policy (1995). GCD agreed that (i) for 
the  expressway,  Guangxi  Communications  Infrastructure  Administration  Bureau  will  apply  the 
national standard for land compensation, which requires a minimum of 16 times annual average 
output value; (ii) for the three local roads, Guangxi Highway Administration Bureau will apply the 
land  compensation  standards  based  on  Document  No.  39  issued  by  Guangxi  Zhuang 
Autonomous Regional People’s Government; and (iii) for the village roads, the ownership of the 
roads  and  lands  will  be  retained  by  the  relevant  village  collective.  The  land  compensation 
standards used for all components are sufficient to meet replacement cost. The relevant village 
committees will ensure that those affected will be compensated through the provision of reserve 
land,  land  readjustment,  cash  payment,  or  payment-in-kind.  For  demolished  structures, 
replacement value will be based on compensation rates in Baise. Those losing housing will be 
able to acquire new housing sites within their existing group or village, and close to a road. All 
sites  will  be  provided  with  water  supply,  electricity,  telephone  and  television  cable,  where 
available.  The  relocated  families  will  receive  moving  allowances  and  temporary  housing 
allowances. 
 
4. 
Detailed  resettlement  and  rehabilitation  plans  for  seriously  affected  villages  will  be 
developed and included in the updated resettlement plan for the expressway component. Based 
on consultations, most people affected prefer to get cash compensation directly to be used to 
expand businesses, improve animal husbandry, plant cash crops and trees, and provide income 
security until they find outside work. New employment and income generation opportunities will 
arise  during  construction  and  after  the  expressway  is  completed.  Expressway  contractors  will 
give priority to affected households in the allocation of unskilled jobs during construction.

5. 
ensure compliance with the approved resettlement plans. For the expressway component, the 
Resettlement  Division  within  the  Longlin–Baise  Expressway  Construction  headquarters  will  be 
directly  responsible  for  coordinating  the  planning,  supervision,  financing,  and  reporting  of 
resettlement for the expressway and connector roads. A resettlement leading group and office 
was  established  in  Baise  on  20  October  2006.  Offices  will  also  be  set  up  in  all  the  relevant 
counties,  and  staff  assigned  in  all  affected  townships  and  villages  to  implement  resettlement. 
For economically vulnerable people, including elderly living alone, disabled, households headed 
by  women,  and  poverty  households,  the  Project  will  provide  additional  training  and  physical 
support. For these measures, GCD has agreed to a budget of 1% of basic resettlement fees. 
 
6. 
The 2004 Land Law requires disclosure and consultation with people affected. Affected 
villages  were  notified  about  the  key  elements  of  the  resettlement  plans  during  meetings  and 
interviews. Information was disclosed through newspapers to all those affected in March 2007. 
During detailed resettlement planning, further notifications and consultations will discuss specific 
impacts and how they will be addressed. In case of grievance, all complaints will be processed 
based on the resettlement plans on Grievance and Redress. 
 
7. 
The requirements for internal and external monitoring and evaluation are included in the 
resettlement  plans.  GCD  will  engage  a  qualified  domestic  monitor  to  carry  out  independent 
monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  monitor  will  conduct  a  baseline  survey  prior  to  resettlement, 
semiannual  investigations  during  resettlement,  and  annual  survey  updates  for  2  years  after 
completion of resettlement; and will provide ADB  and GCD with copies of the reports. For the 
expressway component, an internal monitoring and reporting system will be established in the 
Resettlement  Division  of  the  Longlin–Baise  Expressway  Construction  headquarters  and  report 
to ADB on the progress of land acquisition and resettlement through quarterly progress reports 
and a resettlement completion report. A summary of the resettlement audit will be provided to 
ADB prior to the project completion review mission. For the other project components, internal 
monitoring will be done by GCD and the land and resources bureaus; progress will be reported 
to ADB every 6 months. 
 
8. 
The resettlement budget for the expressway is estimated at CNY600 million, for 6 local 
roads  at  CNY90  million;  and  for  other  components  at  CNY10  million.  Costs  include 
compensation  for  land,  housing,  other  assets,  moving  allowances,  assistance  for  vulnerable 
groups,  infrastructure,  administration,  taxes,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  contingencies. 
GCD will supplement the resettlement budget, as necessary, to meet any shortfall that emerges. 
 
9. 
The  land  acquisition  and  housing  demolition  for  the  expressway  component  will 
commence by September 2007. For the local roads and bus stations, some implementation will 
commence in 2007; village road construction will commence in 2008.
